creditline: Gift of the Clark Center for Japanese Art & Culture
description: image of a ghostly woman wearing loose, flowing kimono; blue eyes glancing outward; open mouth; grey tones except for blue eyes
marks: ULC: [ 應需月岡芳年畫] {Ōju Tsukioka Yoshitoshi kaku}
medium: Hanging scroll; ink and color on silk
text: Yoshitoshi was one of the last masters of <i>ukiyo-e<i> in the Meiji period. A pupil of Utagawa Kuniyoshi (1797–1861), he also studied with Kikuchi Yōsai (1788–1878), a master of historical painting. Yoshitoshi merged the <i>ukiyo-e<i> style with Western realism to produce a new form of print for the modern audience. His historical and heroic prints were often bizarre and ghoulish. This is one of his best paintings with the eyes of the ghost ominously shining in pale blue.
title: Ghost
